label: PTX097 | 6-Propyl-2-thiouracil
source_kow: PP-LFER, Ulrich, N., Endo, S., Brown, T.N., Watanabe, N., Bronner, G., Abraham, M.H., Goss, K.-U., UFZ-LSER database v 3.2.1 [Internet], Leipzig, Germany, Helmholtz Centre for Environmental Research-UFZ. 2017 [accessed on 11.08.2023]. Available from http://www.ufz.de/lserd
moa_drugbank: Propylthiouracil binds to thyroid peroxidase and thereby inhibits the conversion of iodide to iodine. Thyroid peroxidase normally converts iodide to iodine (via hydrogen peroxide as a cofactor) and also catalyzes the incorporation of the resulting iodide molecule onto both the 3 and/or 5 positions of the phenol rings of tyrosines found in thyroglobulin. Thyroglobulin is degraded to produce thyroxine (T4) and tri-iodothyronine (T3), which are the main hormones produced by the thyroid gland. Therefore propylthiouracil effectively inhibits the production of new thyroid hormones.

aop.AOP_name: Androgen receptor antagonism leading to adverse effects in the male foetus (mammals)
LXR activation leading to hepatic steatosis
Inhibition of Na+/I- symporter (NIS) leads to learning and memory impairment
NR1I3 (CAR) suppression leading to hepatic steatosis
NFE2L2/FXR activation leading to hepatic steatosis
Epigenetic modification of PPARG leading to adipogenesis
Anticoagulant rodenticide inhibition of vitamin K epoxide reductase resulting coagulopathy and hemorrhage
